case_name: Ramesh Chandra J. Thakkar v. Parmanand Jhaveri

facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 88 of 1972 was filed by special leave in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 88 of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal directed against judgment and order dated January 24, 1972 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 9 of 1972.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1972 of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revi- sion Application No. 9 of 1972.

facts.text: Parmanand Jhaveri (respondent No. 1) filed two complaints before the Court of the Presidency Magistrate Girgaum against Ramesh Chandra J. Thakkar (appellant) and B. K. Shah.

anchor.surface_text: Parmanand Jhaveri respondent No. 1 filed two companyplaints before the companyrt of the Presidency Magistrate Girgaum against Ramesh Chandra J. Thakkar appellant and B. K. Shah

facts.text: Accused committed offences under section 420 Indian Penal Code and section 13 of the Maharashtra Ownership of Flats Act, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: on the allegation that the two accused persons had companymitted offences under section 420 Indian Penal Code and section 13 of the Maharashtra Ownership of Flats  Regulation

facts.text: Accused agreed to sell two flats to the complainant on February 11, 1967, possession to be delivered on December 31, 1967.

anchor.surface_text: In one of the companyplaints it was stated that the accused had agreed to sell two flats to the companyplainant, while in the second companyplaint there was a similar allegation regarding agreement on the part of the accused to transfer a third plot. The agreement, it was stated, had been entered into on February 11, 1967

facts.text: Accused received Rs. 28,000 from complainant but did not deliver possession of the flats.

anchor.surface_text: According further to the companyplainant, the accused persons in spite of having received Rs. 28,000 from him had number delivered possession of the flats to the companyplainant.

facts.text: B. K. Shah could not be traced, cases proceeded only against appellant.

anchor.surface_text: B. K. Shah accused companyld number be traced and the two companyplaint cases proceeded only against the appellant.

facts.text: Charges framed against appellant on April 2, 1970.

anchor.surface_text: The following charges were framed against the appellant on April 2, 1970 I do hereby- charge you as follows

facts.text: Charges: Failed to make full and true disclosure of the nature of his title to the land.

anchor.surface_text: Failed to make full and true disclosure of the nature of his tide to the land on which he intended to companystruct the flats

facts.text: Charges: Failed to get written agreements registered under Indian Registration Act.

anchor.surface_text: Failed to get the written agreements in respect of flats registered under the Indian Registration Act.

facts.text: Charges: Induced complainant to part with Rs. 28000 on false representation under s.420 IPC, s.3,4,13-14 MOFA.

anchor.surface_text: That you induced the companyplainant to part with Rs. 28000 on false and dishonest representation that you would companystruct flats at Malad and give him three flats of certain area in his possession and thereby companymitted an offence punishable under section 3 and 4 R W. Section 13-14 Maharashtra Ownership Flats Act and section 420 of the Indian Penal Code

facts.text: On April 30, 1970, after some evidence, parties entered agreement, complainant did not wish to proceed, accused acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: On April 30, 1970 after some evidence had been recorded, the trial magistrate passed the following order The parties at this stage put in an agreement whereby the accused undertakes to do certain things within a certain period and-on such undertaking the companyplainant does number wish to proceed with the trial. The accused agreed to the agreement and the case is companypounded and accused acquitted.

facts.text: On August 17, 1970, respondent No. 1 filed application before trial magistrate for contempt as undertaking not fulfilled.

anchor.surface_text: On August 17, 1970 respondent No. 1 filed an application be- fore the trial magistrate stating that though the appellant had undertaken to deliver possession of the flats by a certain date or to pay back the amount in cash, the said undertaking had number been fulfilled.

facts.text: On January 25, 1971, trial magistrate ordered appellant guilty of contempt, directed papers sent to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The trial magistrate passed an order on January 25, 1971 wherein it was stated that the appellant had gone back on his undertaking given to the companyrt and as such was guilty of companytempt of companyrt. The magistrate accordingly directed that papers be sent to the High Court

facts.text: Bombay High Court held not a fit case for contempt action but set aside order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: When the matter came up before the High Court, the learned judges companystituting the Division Bench took the view that it was number a fit case in which act-ion under the Contempt of Courts Act was called for against the appellant. At the same time, the learned judges took the view that it was a fit case in which the order of acquittal

facts.text: High Court gave notice to appellant to show cause why acquittal should not be set aside.

anchor.surface_text: Before that, on an earlier date of hearing, numberice had been given to the appellant to show cause why the order, of acquittal should number be set aside.

facts.text: High Court set aside acquittal and directed trial magistrate to proceed from stage where complainant was persuaded not to press complaints.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court companysequently set aside the order of acquittal and directed the trial magistrate to proceed with the trial in both the companyplaint cases from the stage at which respondent No. 1 had been persuaded to number press-the companyplaints.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal as bereft of merit.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing Mr. Bhandare on behalf of the appellant, Mr. Hingorani on behalf of respondent No. 1 and Mr. Sharma on behalf of the State of Maharashtra, we have companye to the companyclusion that the present appeal is bereft of any merit.

facts.text: Offence under section 420 IPC is compoundable with permission of court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the offence under section 420 Indian Pental Code is companycerned, it is companypoundable with the permission of the companyrt.

facts.text: Offence under section 13 Maharashtra Act is not compoundable.

anchor.surface_text: The offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act is, however, number companypoundable either with or without the permission of the Court.

facts.text: Acquittal based on compounding which was invalid for s.13 offence.

anchor.surface_text: As the said offence was number companypoundable with or without the, permission of the companyrt, the order of the trial magistrate, in our view, in acquitting the accused because of the companyposition of the offences cannot be said to be in accordance with law.

facts.text: No order granting permission to compound s.420 brought to notice.

holdings.text: So far as the offence under section 420 Indian Penal Code is concerned, it is compoundable with the permission of the court.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the offence under section 420 Indian Pental Code is companycerned, it is companypoundable with the permission of the companyrt. The offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act is, however, number companypoundable either with or without the permission of the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct application of CrPC provisions on compoundability; s.420 listed as compoundable with permission.

holdings.text: The offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act is, however, not compoundable either with or without the permission of the Court.

anchor.surface_text: The offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act is, however, number companypoundable either with or without the permission of the Court. According to sub-section (7) of section 345 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, no offence shall be compounded except as provided by this section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.345(7) CrPC prohibits compounding unless provided; s.13 MOFA offence falls under general prohibition as not listed.

holdings.text: As the said offence was not compoundable with or without the permission of the court, the order of the trial magistrate, in our view, in acquitting the accused because of the composition of the offences cannot be said to be in accordance with law.

anchor.surface_text: As the said offence was number companypoundable with or without the, permission of the companyrt, the order of the trial magistrate, in our view, in acquitting the accused because of the companyposition of the offences cannot be said to be in accordance with law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trial court's acquittal based on invalid compounding of non-compoundable s.13 MOFA offence is contrary to law.

holdings.text: It would follow from the above that where an acquittal is based on the compounding of an offence and the compounding is invalid under the law, the acquittal would be liable to be set aside by the High Court in exercise of its revisional powers.

anchor.surface_text: where the acquittal is based on a compounding of the offence, which is invalid under the law. These and other cases of similar nature can properly be held to be cases of exceptional nature, where the High Court can justifiably interfere with an order of acquittal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in K. Chinnaswamy Reddy; invalid compounding creates exceptional circumstance for revisionary interference with acquittal.

holdings.text: As the acquittal of the appellant by the trial court in the present case was based upon the compounding of an offence which was not compoundable, the High Court in our view rightly set aside the acquittal of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It would follow from the above that where an acquittal is based on the companypounding of an offence... the High Court in our view rightly set aside the acquittal of the appellant.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of above principle to facts; HC correctly applied revisional power.

holdings.text: The opening words of section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure... produce the result that revisional jurisdiction can be exercised by the High Court... suo motu on the basis of its own knowledge derived from any source whatsoever without being moved by any person at all.

anchor.surface_text: in view of the provisions of section 439(4) It would follow from the above that where an acquittal is based on the compounding of an offence... The opening words of section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, viz, In the case of any proceedings the record of which has been called for by itself

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation of s.439 CrPC opening words; confirmed by precedent in State of Kerala v. Narayani Amma.

holdings.text: It is not doubtful true that the High Court acted suo motu in setting aside the acquittal of the appellant, but that fact would not show that there was any irregularity in the procedure adopted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is numberdoubt true that the High Court acted suo motu in setting aside the acquittal of the appellant, but that fact would number show that there was any irregularity in the procedure adopted by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suo motu action valid as per s.439; no procedural irregularity.

holdings.text: No order granting such permission has been brought to our notice.

anchor.surface_text: No order granting such permission has been brought to our numberice. Even if we were to assume that such permission was granted, as submitted by Mr. Bhandare, we do number know the precise language

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of evidence of permission for s.420 compounding.

holdings.text: All the same it appears that the said permission was one indivisible permission for the offences under section 420 Indian Penal Code and section 13 of the Maharashtra Act. As no valid permission could be granted for the compounding of an offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act, the permission would have to be held to be invalid in its entirety.

anchor.surface_text: All the same it appears that the said permission was one indivisible permission for the offences under section 420 Indian Penal Code and section 13 of the Maharashtra Act. As no valid permission could be granted for the compounding of an offence under section 13

holdings.reasoning_summary: Compounding permission for multiple offences indivisible; invalidity for non-compoundable taints entire permission.

holdings.text: It is not permissible in, such an event to sever the permission into two parts and to uphold it so far as the offence under section 420 Indian Penal, Code is concerned and hold it to be invalid in respect of the offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act.

anchor.surface_text: It is number permissible in, such an event to sever the permission into two parts and to uphold it so far as the offence under section 420 Indian Penal, Code is companycerned and hold it to be invalid in respect of the offence under section 13 of the Maharashtra Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cannot sever permission; must invalidate wholly if partly invalid.

holdings.text: The present appeal is bereft of any merit.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing Mr. Bhandare on behalf of the appellant, Mr. Hingorani on behalf of respondent No. 1 and Mr. Sharma on behalf of the State of Maharashtra, we have companye to the companyclusion that the present appeal is bereft of any merit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative application of above holdings to facts; upholds HC order.
